title: AP Carries, AP assassins and AP fighters all use the same items....

replies.body:
The main issue is that AP champions simply all utilize AP and CDR equally well. Sure, there is some variety in how most use mana and some do not and how some burst more and some burst less, however all that varies depending on the meta.

But you are wrong about one thing: this being a disadvantage for AP. This simply means that AD champions appear to have more chioices - which is theoretically true - however in reality most AD champions have less options than AP champions as they can only utilize some AD items while many AP champions can use practically all AP items to some degree.

Let's take {{champion:136}}  as an example of an all-around mage who benefits both from bulkiness and pure damage.
Even if he can use effectively a vast majority of the AP items roster, some are just useless to him, namely {{item:3100}} {{item:3115}} . Now, this is a poor example since those two items are barely usable for a vast majority of AP users. But we can still remove some items, like {{item:3041}} {{item:3089}} {{item:3157}} {{item:3907}} {{item:2065}} . The first 2 because of how far you need to be ahead to both either build or use those to even BE a decent build option. Zhonya is a little tricky, but to put it short, it brings barely anything considering how this item has been nerfed, from active cooldown to amount of AP to armor being a joke anywhere in the game, so objectively, this item is very situational. Now, spellbinder is barely used and its just obvious why since it brings not much while coming with a powerfull active... that you can't use most of the time because of how long it needs to stay innactive to even remotely be relevant. Now, shurelya should almost be brought to {{item:3174}}  and {{item:3504}}  in terms of AP items utility since it barely brings raw stats to AP champions (who are, possibly, the most raw-stat dependant champs in the game most of the time) while being focused on being supportive and the same can be said about {{item:3905}} . If we go even FURTER, {{item:3027}} and {{item:3003}} , to a lesser extent, can also be considered ireelevant SITUATIONALY, since both those items also need stacking and can be intirely irrelevant to build at certain points in the game where the early/mid game is gone since the game are so short nowadays that those are barely options at some point.

Without even going furter and using a mage ({{champion:136}} ) that can use a majority of the ap item roster (even this abomination {{item:3030}} ), we can objectively say that his AP item roster is approximately and situationaly between 8 to 12 items out of about 18 usable AP items. This ranges from about 45 to 65 percent of usable (!!!) item roster situationnaly!! With this example, how the hell is this statement true when compaired to AD champions?? :

>  in reality most AD champions have less options than AP champions as they can only utilize some AD items while many AP champions can use practically all AP items to some degree

https://i.imgur.com/BEQYFjQ.gif[/img]

Some examples, like {{champion:112}} , can't even make use of some more items because of other reasons! And this is only covering classic mages, it only gets worse for other AP scaling classes...

If we get to the AD part, how the hell is this even remotely comparable? The only items I can think of who "can't" be used by AD champions because of whatever reason are the melee/ranged limited ones ({{item:3748}} {{item:3074}} {{item:3085}} ), {{item:3004}}  and only recently {{item:3031}} . If an AD build ever gets repetitive its only because some items are far more effective together or just plainly stronger. If the same happens with AP builds, it just because, well, in 5 items post-boots you barely have any choicce on what you build so you end up with the same 2 or 3 builds for more than half of the AP roster!

Exactly. See, this is the problem. Mage players are upset because they want more armor, but don't want to miss out on CDR or mana on their first item.

But that item already exists. It's {{item:3110}} , an item which is not only remarkably cheap for its stats but also very strong against Talon and Zed.

The problem is that mage players simply REFUSE to buy items that do not grant them AP, even though those items do buff their offense by giving them CDR and mana to use their base damage more often.

A) Mage players don't want to be _WORTHLESS_ because they skipped AP outside of any utility they may or may not have.

B) Armor without HP to back it is essentially worthless with all of then Armor Pen running around especially with the Last Whisper revert.

C) You will have 0 waveclear with a Frozen Heart because you are not meeting AP thresholds.

C1) You will just be shoved in all day and ignored while the Assassin roams.

I would rather "be WORTHLESS" then be sitting with a gray screen half the game.  A living mage with 400 AP does infinitely more damage than a dead mage with 600 AP.

When did I say that I'm everyone?  Also, building a single frozen heart for 2700 gold giving you enough mana for most champions and 20% cdr as well as the highest armor available in a single item is enough to keep yourself from getting bursted.  You still have 4 slots for other items.

I had a game on Sivir where I kept getting one shot by the enemy Rengar.  Instead of whining that Rengar is broken and not adapting I built an Iceborn guantlet.  Just by building a single item I went from him killing me when I use flash, heal, and ult to me killing him without having sums up.  Sure, I may not do quite as much damage as if I had bought another crit item and could some how stay alive, but I still did way more damage in total due to not being dead every time Rengar pressed R.

AP DID get new itemization earlier this year. {{item:3907}} {{item:3905}} {{item:2065}} 

problem is it didnt really fix the problems with the itemization it just added more fluff :s. It's not bad but it didn't really change anything either. I would best describe them as "4fun" items.

My biggest problems with AP Itemization are.

1. {{item:3089}} being a blanket multipler for EVERYTHING while not actually introducing or adding interesting of cool gameplay. It doesnt have any sort of useful utility effect that can shape how you will play the game like Rylai's slow, gunblade healing or Nashors on-hit effect. its just flat out more damage and scaling across the board for the SAKE of more damage and scaling across the board.  Really lame item and I think its passive is far overdue for a rework.
Rabbadons should actually have a niche set of users (preferably those looking to maximize damage like Kennen,Fiddlesticks or Katarina) rather than being a "cant go wrong" item applicable to literally anyone who builds AP. I mean even old Infinity wasn't bought on EVERY AD champion (Juggs/Bruisers/Assassins). 

2. too reliant on the {{item:3135}} {{item:3165}} /{{item:3020}}  double pen interaction. I think we need a 3rd answer to resist stacking. something thats in between hardcore 200 Resist (where void should be picked up) but better than the base 30 Sorc and Morello give which is just enough to cause true damage from spells but feels terrible after the infamous {{item:3156}} {{item:3111}} pick up. Honestly I kinda wish {{item:3091}}  built into an actual AP item that let its shred passive apply on spell instances not just basics. That might be a good answer of some sort.

3. Because of the really sterile build directions its extremely hard for {{item:3115}} to shine in the same room as {{item:3100}} . Any champ who would build Nash is probably just better off getting Lich and calling it a day. Both the DESIGN of AP melee champions and the ITEMS of melee AP champions tend to not support sustained fighting. Hell even when it comes to takin down towers LichBanes burst proc will give WAY more damage than the 50% AS from Nashor. Nashor really seems to be for On-Hit Rageblade builds rather than actual AP builds despite the AP scaling. On that note I feel like it kinda needs a slight redesign along with some new "AP Right click" items thats not just Ragebalde/Nash.

AD has different itemization because they can focus on 2 things instead of 1.  AD has the option to either focus on auto attacks (ADCs) or focus on casting abilities (AD Assassins and other AD casters).  All the champions that like to build AP only really focus on using abilities rather than auto attacks (aside from a select few) so they all build similar items.  It's not Riot being biased towards AD it's just how the game has always been designed.  AD has the option of building around auto attacking or building around using abilities and AP only has the option of building around using abilities.

How would you create diversity within the 3 AP classes?  Every AP item that I have ever thought of that would be geared towards AP Assassins could easily be used/abused by a multitude of mages.  Almost every AP item that people have suggested to be dedicated towards mages or fighters could easily be built by the other classes.  It's just how AP works.  If you wanted a lot of diversity within AP build paths and champions, then you would have to completely rework how the whole system of Ability Power works.

It is **A LOT** easier said than done.

Plus, you have to understand, that it's much easier to homogenize AP items since most of them being casters (meaning your damage output though abilities) the only 2 things they care about are 1) Ability Power 2) Cooldown Reduction.

AD items on the other hand have much more variance in how their damage is output. Those whose damage comes primarily from basic attacks will often want to focus on attack speed/critical strike/on-hit. Seldom will you see AP-builders stack attack speed stats, therefore items for AP-Attack Speed items are severely limited as you can see with {{item:3115}}. 

Additionally, AP-builders have more or less similar playstyles. They don't have as many variances in their sub-classes. It's generally just mage, with like 1 or 2 fighters, 2 assassins, 2 tanks. Whereas AD-builders are typically labelled as marksman, assassin, fighter, tank.

I'm sure if you were to categorize the champs by primary adaptive stat AD or AP, **then** categorize each stat-group by primary role/class, you'll see that AP builders are primarily mages.
